logo: Ameren Illinois Visible Elements : â€¢ The logo consists of a stylized green circular burst with one red segment, positioned to the left of the text. â€¢ The word "Ameren" appears in bold, black italicized font. â€¢ The word "ILLINOIS" is written below "Ameren" in uppercase, gray, non-italicized font. â€¢ No additional taglines, dates, or graphic elements are present. â€¢ The logo is on a white background. Dimensions & Placement : â€¢ The circular burst is approximately the same height as the text "Ameren". â€¢ "ILLINOIS" is centered below "Ameren" and is smaller in size. Analysis : â€¢ The use of green and the burst motif may suggest energy, growth, or sustainability, aligning with Ameren Illinois's identity as a utility company. â€¢ The red segment adds visual emphasis and may represent a spark or highlight within the burst. Summary : This image shows two social media logos, Facebook and Twitter, in grayscale, side by side. logo: Logos & Elements : â€¢ Facebook "f" logo on the left, rendered in dark gray. â€¢ Twitter bird logo on the right, also in dark gray. â€¢ Both logos are simple, flat, and lack any text or additional design elements. â€¢ No company names or taglines are present. â€¢ The logos are spaced apart on a white background. Dimensions & Placement : â€¢ Both logos are approximately the same height. â€¢ Facebook logo is on the left, Twitter logo is on the right, with clear separation between them. Analysis : â€¢ The use of grayscale rather than brand colours suggests a neutral or inactive state, possibly for a UI element such as a disabled share button or a monochrome design. ![inline icon: white circle with green 'i' for information] Important Account Messages Summary : This bar chart presents the monthly electric usage history in kilowatt hours (kWh) alongside the average monthly temperature (Â°F) for a one-year period, allowing comparison of energy consumption with seasonal temperature changes. bar chart: Title & Axes : â€¢ Title: "Electric Usage History in Kilowatt Hours (kWh)". â€¢ X-axis: Months (from May to the following May), each labeled with the average monthly temperature in Â°F. â€¢ Y-axis: Electric usage in kilowatt hours (kWh), with values shown above each bar. Data Points : â€¢ May (58Â°): 2080 kWh â€¢ Jun (72Â°): 1920 kWh â€¢ Jul (74Â°): 1920 kWh â€¢ Aug (76Â°): 1760 kWh â€¢ Sep (75Â°): 1920 kWh â€¢ Oct (66Â°): 1760 kWh â€¢ Nov (47Â°): 2080 kWh â€¢ Dec (39Â°): 2240 kWh â€¢ Jan (29Â°): 2240 kWh â€¢ Feb (24Â°): 1440 kWh â€¢ Mar (39Â°): 1600 kWh â€¢ Apr (44Â°): 1440 kWh â€¢ May (63Â°): 1280 kWh Design Encodings : â€¢ Each month is represented by a vertical bar; all bars are light blue except the final May bar, which is a darker blue. â€¢ Average monthly temperature is shown below each month as a small number with a degree symbol. â€¢ Usage values are displayed numerically above each bar. Distribution & Trends : â€¢ Electric usage is highest in December and January (2240 kWh each). â€¢ Usage is also relatively high in the summer months (Mayâ€“September), with values ranging from 1760 to 2080 kWh. â€¢ The lowest usage occurs in the final May (1280 kWh), with other low points in February (1440 kWh), March (1600 kWh), and April (1440 kWh). â€¢ Temperatures are highest in July, August, and September (74Â°â€“76Â°), and lowest in January and February (29Â°, 24Â°). Analysis : â€¢ Electric usage peaks during the coldest months (December and January), suggesting increased heating demand. â€¢ There is a secondary, less pronounced peak in the warmer months (Mayâ€“September), likely due to cooling needs. â€¢ Usage drops in the milder months (April, May, October), corresponding to moderate temperatures. â€¢ The pattern indicates a strong seasonal relationship between temperature extremes and higher electric consumption.
Average Daily Electric Use (kWh)
TIME PERIOD AVG. DAILY USE
CURRENT MONTH 41.29 kWh
LAST MONTH 48.00 kWh
LAST YEAR 71.72 kWh
Summary : This bar chart displays monthly gas usage in therms alongside average monthly temperatures over a one-year period, highlighting seasonal variation in energy consumption. bar chart: Title & Axes : â€¢ Title: "Gas Usage History in Therms". â€¢ X-axis: Months (MAY, JUN, JUL, AUG, SEP, OCT, NOV, DEC, JAN, FEB, MAR, APR, MAY) with corresponding average monthly temperatures (Â°F) below each month. â€¢ Y-axis: Gas usage in therms (values shown above each bar). Data Points : â€¢ MAY (58Â°): 198 therms â€¢ JUN (72Â°): 10 therms â€¢ JUL (74Â°): 0 therms â€¢ AUG (76Â°): 2 therms â€¢ SEP (75Â°): 0 therms â€¢ OCT (66Â°): 16 therms â€¢ NOV (46Â°): 575 therms â€¢ DEC (39Â°): 687 therms â€¢ JAN (29Â°): 1200 therms â€¢ FEB (24Â°): 925 therms â€¢ MAR (39Â°): 357 therms â€¢ APR (45Â°): 190 therms â€¢ MAY (63Â°): 18 therms Design Encodings : â€¢ Bars are light blue. â€¢ Each bar is labeled with its exact value above. â€¢ Average monthly temperature is shown below each month in smaller text. Distribution & Trends : â€¢ Gas usage is lowest (0â€“16 therms) from June through October, when temperatures are highest (66â€“76Â°F). â€¢ Usage rises sharply in November (575 therms) as temperatures drop (46Â°F), peaking in January (1200 therms, 29Â°F). â€¢ After January, usage declines as temperatures rise, with a secondary peak in February (925 therms, 24Â°F). â€¢ Usage remains elevated through March (357 therms, 39Â°F) and April (190 therms, 45Â°F), then drops again in May (18 therms, 63Â°F). Analysis : â€¢ Gas usage is strongly inversely correlated with average monthly temperature: highest in the coldest months (Decemberâ€“February) and lowest in the warmest months (Juneâ€“September). â€¢ The most pronounced peak occurs in January, coinciding with the lowest average temperature. â€¢ There is a clear seasonal pattern, with minimal gas usage during summer and a sharp increase as temperatures fall in late autumn and winter.
TIME PERIOD AVG. DAILY USE
CURRENT MONTH 0.64 Therms
LAST MONTH 6.13 Therms
LAST YEAR 6.83 Therms

Alphanumeric String : â€¢ String below barcode: ">002948 2072404 0001 092139 10Z". â€¢ Additional annotation: "*****AUTO**SCH 5-DIGIT 61401". Address Block : â€¢ Recipient: MIDSTATE MANUFACTURING HEAVY FAB LLC â€¢ Street: 750 W 3RD ST â€¢ City/State/ZIP: GALESBURG, IL 61401-5829 Placement & Format : â€¢ Barcode is placed above the address block, standard for automated mail processing. â€¢ All text is in uppercase, monospaced font, typical for machine readability. Analysis : â€¢ The barcode and associated codes are used for automated mail sorting and delivery by the USPS. â€¢ The address is formatted for business mail, with ZIP+4 for precise delivery. â€¢ The presence of both barcode and human-readable codes ensures redundancy and compatibility with postal automation systems. Summary : This image shows a postal barcode and mailing address for Ameren Illinois, including a PO Box and city/state/ZIP information. barcode: Barcode Details : â€¢ Linear barcode appears above the address block. â€¢ No human-readable numeric or alphanumeric string is visible. â€¢ Barcode type is not explicitly labeled; likely a USPS POSTNET or Intelligent Mail Barcode based on format. â€¢ Approximate module count: 65 vertical bars. â€¢ Quiet zone: present on both left and right edges. Address Block : â€¢ AMEREN ILLINOIS â€¢ PO BOX 88034 â€¢ CHICAGO IL 60680-1034 Placement & Dimensions : â€¢ Barcode is horizontally aligned above the address, spanning the full width of the address block. â€¢ Address is left-aligned, in all uppercase letters. Analysis : â€¢ The barcode is used for automated mail sorting and delivery by the USPS, encoding the destination ZIP+4 and possibly additional routing information for the address listed below. 40700000 0070384800200 000000267250 000000267250 logo: Ameren Illinois Visible Text and Design : â€¢ The logo displays the company name "Ameren" in bold black letters, with "ILLINOIS" in smaller, uppercase, gray letters beneath it. â€¢ To the left of the text is a circular, radiating green graphic with a single red segment, resembling a stylized sunburst or turbine. The overall design is clean and modern, reinforcing a professional brand identity for Ameren Illinois. Spatial Relationships : â€¢ The icons are separated by a small amount of white space. â€¢ Both are centered vertically within the crop. Analysis : â€¢ The use of monochrome gray suggests a neutral or inactive state, possibly for use as generic social media links or buttons. â€¢ The pairing of Facebook and Twitter indicates a focus on mainstream social media platforms. Dimensions & Placement : â€¢ The graphic is positioned to the left of the text. â€¢ "Ameren" is the most prominent text, with "ILLINOIS" smaller and directly underneath. Analysis : â€¢ The use of green and the radiating lines in the logo may suggest energy, growth, or sustainability, aligning with Ameren Illinois's identity as a utility company. Summary : This image shows two social media platform logos, Facebook and Twitter, in grayscale, side by side. logo: Platforms & Design : â€¢ Facebook "f" logo on the left, rendered in dark gray. â€¢ Twitter bird logo on the right, also in dark gray. â€¢ Both logos are presented without any accompanying text or tagline. â€¢ The logos are spaced apart on a white background. â€¢ No additional graphical elements, borders, or annotations are present. Dimensions & Placement : â€¢ Both logos are approximately the same height. â€¢ Facebook logo is positioned to the left; Twitter logo to the right. Analysis : â€¢ The use of grayscale rather than brand colours suggests a neutral or inactive state, possibly for use as generic social media icons or share buttons. Analysis :
  â€¢ Gas usage is strongly inversely correlated with average monthly temperature: highest in the coldest months (Decemberâ€“February) and lowest in the warmest months (Juneâ€“September).
  â€¢ The most pronounced peak occurs in January, coinciding with the lowest average temperature.
  â€¢ There is a clear seasonal pattern, with minimal gas usage during summer and a sharp increase as temperatures fall in late autumn and winter.
